item.title: Thailand Confident of Lowering US Tariff With Trade Offers
item.description: Thailand remains optimistic about securing a lower tariff rate than the 36% levy announced by President Donald Trump, based on its offer to reduce import tax on most US goods to zero, Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira said.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana, Pathom Sangwongwanich

item.title: European Group Decries China’s New Medical Device Restrictions
item.description: A European business group in China has criticized Beijing’s retaliatory measures targeting medical device makers from the European Union, saying the move worsens ties between the two economic powers.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: Photo by Sebastian Kahnert/picture alliance via Getty Images)

item.title: South Korea Vows to Fix Rules After Trump’s New Tariff Deadline
item.description: South Korea said it will look at regulations raised by the US and press ahead with trade negotiations after President Donald Trump sent a letter to the Asian ally with a new August deadline for imposing 25% across-the-board tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Heesu Lee

media:content.media:description: Container ships are docked as shipping containers sit in the Busan Port Terminal (BPT) in this aerial photograph taken in Busan, South Korea, on Tuesday, Oct. 13, 2020. South Korea’s central bank left its key interest rate unchanged on Wednesday amid signs that a resurgence of the coronavirus at home is waning and exports and inflation are picking up.

item.title: Philippines Summons Chinese Envoy After Ex-Senator Sanctioned
item.description: The Philippine government has summoned China’s envoy to Manila, expressing concern over Beijing’s recent rare move to sanction a former senator who it accused of improper behavior on issues related to China.
item.dc:creator: Manolo Serapio Jr

item.title: Can Anyone in Britain Run a Government?
item.description: The UK is failing to produce a competent governing class.
item.dc:creator: Adrian Wooldridge

media:content.media:description: 11 June 2025, Great Britain, London: A "Diverted traffic" sign near the British Parliament. Photo: Julia Kilian/dpa (Photo by Julia Kilian/picture alliance via Getty Images)

item.title: EU to Give Final Nod to Bulgaria’s Euro-Zone Entry Next Year
item.description: Bulgaria is set to clear the final hurdle to becoming the 21st member of the euro zone next year as European Union finance ministers meet Tuesday to sign off on its bid.
item.dc:creator: Slav Okov

item.title: Iran’s Khamenei Looks to the Past For Route to Regime Survival
item.description: Senior clerics and military figures are looking to leverage Iran's nationalist history to try and forge unity in the polarized country.
item.dc:creator: Golnar Motevalli

media:content.media:description: Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei attends an Ashura ceremony in Tehran, Iran, on July 5.

item.title: Bessent Aims to Meet With Chinese Official in Next Few Weeks
item.description: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said that he expected to meet with his Chinese counterpart in the coming weeks to advance discussions on trade and other issues between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US secretary of the treasury, speaks to members of the media after a Senate Republican policy luncheon at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, June 27, 2025. President Donald Trump amped up pressure on Congress to speed the passage of his tax-cut bill as Republicans reached a tentative deal on the state and local tax deduction, one of the key sticking points in the negotiations.

item.title: Malaysia Commits to Trade Talks After Higher US Tariff Threat
item.description: Malaysia said it will continue to engage with the US after President Donald Trump threatened to impose a steeper tariff rate unless the Southeast Asian nation reaches an agreement with his administration.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry

item.title: Japan, Korea Keep Pushing for Lower US Tariffs as Deadline Moves
item.description: Japan and South Korea said they’ll keep pushing for a better deal for their exports to the US after President Donald Trump shifted his tariff deadline to Aug. 1 and tweaked the rates he’s set for many economies.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara, Soo-Hyang Choi

item.title: TSA Set to Let Travelers Keep Shoes on Through Airport Security
item.description: US travelers may soon no longer have to worry about removing their shoes to go through standard airport security checkpoints, a change that will likely speed up screening for airline passengers.
item.dc:creator: Allyson Versprille, Myles Miller

media:content.media:description: ROBYN BECK/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: ROBYN BECK/AFP

item.title: Trump Promises More Weapons for Ukraine and Criticizes Putin
item.description: President Donald Trump said he’d ship more weapons to Ukraine, marking an apparent reversal after the Pentagon halted flows of some air-defense missiles and artillery shells to the country.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Akayla Gardner, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump on July 7. Photographer: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Japan Gets 25% Tariffs With Room to Seek Deal Past Election
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba called the announcement of slightly higher US tariffs “truly regrettable” while he vowed to continue to protect his nation’s interests in the extended trade negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

item.title: EU Rushes to Conclude Framework Trade Deal With US This Week
item.description: The European Union is seeking to conclude a preliminary trade deal with the US this week that would allow it to lock in a 10% tariff rate beyond an Aug. 1 deadline as they negotiate a permanent agreement.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: Operations at the HHLA Hamburg Container Terminal Altenwerder in the Port of Hamburg.

item.title: Trump Issues New Tariff Rates, Still Open to Negotiations
item.description: President Donald Trump unveiled the first in a wave of promised letters that threaten to impose higher tariff rates on key trading partners, but suggested that he was still open to additional negotiations and pushed off increased duties until at least Aug. 1.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Catherine Lucey, Stephanie Lai

item.title: Netanyahu Says He Nominated Trump for Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told President Donald Trump he nominated him for the Nobel Peace Prize, using a visit to the White House to further cement the pair’s relationship as the US presses for a ceasefire in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Kate Sullivan, Stephanie Lai

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump with Benjamin Netanyahu in April 2025. Photographer: Saul Loeb/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Plans Texas Trip This Week to Survey Flood Devastation
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would travel to Texas on Friday, a trip that will allow him to survey first-hand the devastation from extreme floods that have left at least 100 people dead and scores still missing.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Stephanie Lai

media:content.media:description: A resident walks through debris during search and rescue efforts in Center Point, Texas, on July 06. Photographer: Brandon Bell/Getty Images

item.title: UK Is Moving to Ban NDAs to Hide Misconduct, Guardian Reports
item.description: The UK government is moving to ban employers deploying nondisclosure agreements to muzzle workers who have been victims of misconduct on the job, the Guardian reported on Monday.
item.dc:creator: John Harney

item.title: Trump Orders Stricter Enforcement of Clean Energy Tax Rules
item.description: US President Donald Trump called for new rules that would restrict access to tax incentives for solar and wind projects that already had been pared back by his $3.4 trillion budget bill designed to end green energy incentives.
item.dc:creator: Mark Chediak

item.title: Lawyers Say New Evidence Challenges Trump on El Salvador Prisons
item.description: Lawyers for Venezuelans sent to a prison in El Salvador claim new evidence “contradicts” the US government’s claims that Salvadoran officials, not the Trump administration, have legal authority over the men.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: Prison officers stand guard at maximum security penitentiary CECOT (Center for the Compulsory Housing of Terrorism) on April 4, 2025 in Tecoluca, San Vicente, El Salvador.

item.title: Rubio Heads to Malaysia for Summit Under Shadow of Tariffs
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio is set to make his first trip to Asia as the top US diplomat this week, heading to a regional summit in Malaysia a day after President Donald Trump threatened a new 25% tariff on the country and several others.
item.dc:creator: Eric Martin

media:content.media:description: Signage for the 46th Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Photographer: He Guowei/VCG/Getty Images

item.title: Carney’s Cabinet Searches for Spending Cuts as Defense Bill Grows
item.description: Canada’s finance minister has asked members of cabinet to find billions of dollars in spending cuts as the government looks for ways to pay for a larger defense budget and capital projects.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt

media:content.media:description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney, right, and Minister of National Defence David McGuinty meet with Canadian troops at the Fort York Armoury in Toronto, on June 9.

item.title: Second Ship Hit in Red Sea After Earlier Houthi Attack
item.description: A second vessel was attacked by five rocket-propelled grenades in the Red Sea near Yemen, just a few hours after Houthis claimed responsibility for an earlier attack on a ship sailing in the same area, making voyages through the key region dangerous again.
item.dc:creator: Mohammed Hatem, Sherif Tarek, Catherine Cartier

item.title: Trump Gives Himself Overtime Period to Cut Trade Deals
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, White House correspondent Josh Wingrove looks at the president’s latest tariff threats and deadline. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

item.title: Carney Says New Oil Pipeline Proposal Likely in Canada
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney said a new oil pipeline to Canada’s West Coast is “highly likely” to be proposed as a nation-building project, which could mean it becomes part of Ottawa’s push to fast-track major developments under new legislation.
item.dc:creator: Paula Sambo

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada's prime minister, speaks at LeBreton Flats on Canada Day in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Tuesday, July 1, 2025. Canada Day, which has been celebrated since 1868, also coincides this year with the 60th anniversary of the Canadian flag.

item.title: Spending Law’s Medicaid Limits Spur Planned Parenthood Suit
item.description: Planned Parenthood is suing the Trump administration over its new multitrillion-dollar tax and spending law, claiming it unconstitutionally targets the group by barring its health centers from receiving Medicaid reimbursement for reproductive health care.
item.dc:creator: Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: Sign at entry of Planned Parenthood clinic, This clinic is in Pullman Washington. (Photo by: Don and Melinda Crawford/UCG/Universal Images Group via Getty Images)

item.title: Tracking Every Trump Tariff and Its Economic Effect
item.description: For the full experience visit: Tracking Every Trump Tariff and Its Economic Effect
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Diamond, Adrian Leung, Jane Pong, Christopher Udemans, Jason Kao

item.title: US Removes Terrorist Designation of Syrian Rebel Group HTS
item.description: The US State Department is revoking the foreign terrorist designation of an Islamist rebel group that played a key role in downfall of Bashar Al-Assad’s regime in Syria, a week after President Donald Trump ordered the termination of sanctions on the country.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: Soldiers from Hayat Tahrir al-Sham march through Umayyad Square during a mourning demonstration in Damascus, on Dec 27.

item.title: Four Dead in Kenya Protests as Police Shut Capital City Down
item.description: At least 11 people were killed in violent clashes between Kenyan police and protesters demanding the removal of President William Ruto.
item.dc:creator: Simon Marks, David Herbling

media:content.media:description: A man walks past a barbed wire barricade set up by police outside parliament ahead of possible Saba Saba Day demonstrations in Nairobi on July 7, 2025. Kenya marked its fight for democracy on July 7, 2025 with police blocking main roads in Nairobi ahead of potential protests, after last month's demonstrations descended into violent clashes. Saba Saba Day marks the uprising on July 7, 1990 when Kenyans demanded a return to multi-party democracy after years of autocratic rule by then-president Daniel arap Moi. (Photo by Tony KARUMBA / AFP) (Photo by TONY KARUMBA/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Newest US Navy Aircraft Carrier Faces 20-Month Delivery Delay
item.description: Delivery of the Navy’s newest aircraft carrier, the USS John F. Kennedy, is likely to be pushed to March 2027 from this month because of production challenges, according to a newly disclosed budget document.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio
